title: uk weather forecast 33c so hot lorries melt into road
story: Stunned locals in Newbury, Berks, found the stuck truck blocking a street after its wheels became lodged in the liquid tarmac in 30C heat yesterday.Photos emerged as today shapes up to be the hottest day of the summer scorcher so far.The heat is expected to top the previous 2018 record of 32C — making Friday the hottest day of the year.London and the South East will bear the brunt of the sweltering conditions — which will last into tomorrows sport-packed Super Saturday as England take on Sweden in the World Cup quarter final.Hundreds were seen queuing up in blistering sunshine for Wimbledon tickets this morning while revellers at the NASS Festival in Somerset soaked up the rays.Weather forecaster Emma Salter said: Theres no let up in sight in terms of the dry weather and high temperatures through the week.She added: Its pretty much dry across the board and no sign of rain.Temperatures will reach a still blazing 31C tomorrow with sunshine for most sending Brits flocking to beer gardens across the country.Pub industry insiders predict an extra 8million pints will be sold on Saturday — netting landlords £24million more in revenue than a typical day.Storms had been predicted for Friday earlier in the week but Ms Salter said these were now looking very unlikely and had been removed from the forecast.Scotland might see some rain in the coming days, she said, but the rest of the country could expect it to stay dry until the middle of July.She added: From Monday or Tuesday the really high temperatures will start to gradually come down, but it will still be in the high 20s so it will be less hot rather than cooler.On Thursday there were flash floods in Kent following a sudden downpour after a long stretch of scorching weather and uninterrupted sunshine left the ground unable to absorb the deluge.The thunderstorm in Tunbridge Wells led to train and bus delays.Video posted online showed fast-moving water gushing through streets in the town after around 20 minutes of rainfall between 4pm and 5pm on Thursday, the Met Office said.And in Herefordshire dramatic photos showed the River Teme all but disappeared after evaporating in the parched conditions.Environment Agency workers desperately rushed to rescue more than 500 salmon and trout trapped in isolated pockets of water before they vanished in the heat.There are fears that continuous dry weather expected over the coming days — expected to beat the record hot spell of 1976 — could cause similar problems with the Upper River Wye also currently at a low level.The government has asked for the public to conserve more water and take no longer than four minutes in the shower.A hosepipe ban has also been enforced in Northern Ireland amid record temperatures, with Belfast recording 29.5C this week.

title: spot snake australia grass black snake
story: Lockie Golding uploaded a series of pictures to his Facebook page on Wednesday, asking followers to see if they could spot the snake in the bushland.The pictures were taken near the Sunshine Coast, next to a popular walking track.What you’re looking for is a venomous red-bellied black snake.Only a couple of people managed to correctly guess where the serpent was lurking.Although Golding did admit it was one of the hardest games of spot the snake he had done.One thought it was hidden in the very bottom right while another thought it was curved around a bottom branch more to the left?The snake is native to eastern Australia and can be a common sight in urban areas.It can grow up to nearly seven feet long.While the snakes bite is venomous it is usually not fatal.The snake can usually be found in woodland, plains and bushland areas and is often seen close to dams and streams, preferring shallow water containing plants and logs.They are normally active during the day usually preying on frogs, small mammals and reptiles, including other snakes.While a human is unlikely to die from being bitten by one they can cause some nasty health problems, including nausea, vomiting, headaches and diarrhoea, and immediate medical attention is needed.

title: kfc tattoo aussie schoolie free chicken
story: Brooke Collins won the $5,200 (£2,900)“Chicken Cheque” for her entry on the KFC Facebook page, where fans were asked to leave a comment explaining why they deserved the prize.The 19-year-old school-leaver - known as a schoolie in Australia - was crowned “Queen of Chicken 2018” for her and a friend’s matching KFC tatts.She wrote: “If that doesn’t show dedication and love for KFC then I dunno what does.”Brooke, from Sydney, said she and her pal Brielle Sharkie “both had a bond over KFC during year 12, and both wanted to get matching tattoos at Schoolies”.She explained: “I ended up making a status to see if we would get a certain amount of likes and we would get it, and obviously we did.“So we got to the Gold Coast and had time to kill before check-in, and basically went and got the tattoos after being at Schoolies for not even half an hour!“The tattoo shop people honestly could not believe us when we asked for what we wanted.”The winning prize entitles her to $100 (£55) worth of KFC products each week, for 52 weeks.Brooke, who works at a physiotherapy clinic, said it was a “big deal for me”.She said: “Brielle and I always were hoping something crazy would come out of it, and here it is.”Earlier, KFC chief marketing officer Angela Richards said the fast-food chain was looking for weird and wacky stories, or chicken-loving tributes, to mark National Fried Chicken Day on July 6.A number of other entries also featured KFC tattoos.Angela said:“National Fried Chicken Day is quite obviously one of our favourite calendar dates, so we wanted to do something special not only for the joy of fried chicken but the people who adore KFC the most.“Nothing says, ‘I love the amazing taste of the Colonel’s secret recipe fried chicken’, more than a year’s supply of the Colonel’s finest.“We’re looking for hilarious stories, wacky anecdotes and huge displays of immense love for KFC tasty fried chicken to help us choose our overall winner. The bigger and bolder the story, the better!”Brooke isnt the first Aussie to get a KFC-inspired tattoo.The Sun Online told in October how Tom Fletcher, from New South Wales, showed his true love for the chain by getting the name of his favourite dish - the Zinger stacker - inked on his torso in Arabic.

title: boss of plane giant airbus says theresa may has no clue how to carry out brexit without harming uk
story: In an extraordinary rant, Chief Executive Tom Enders said he was RIGHT to issue doom and gloom warnings over the potential impact of us leaving the EU.Speaking this morning at an annual company media briefing held just before Theresa May gathers her ministers for a crunch summit, he said the government didnt know how to avoid the consequences of Brexit.He said: The sun is shining brightly on the UK, the English team is progressing towards the final, the RAF is preparing to celebrate its centenary and Her Majestys Government still has no clue, no consensus on how to execute Brexit without severe harm.And he went on to say the situation was very discomforting for us - and that they owed it to their shareholders to reveal their fears publicly.It comes just weeks after the company threatened to pull thousands of British jobs out of the country over our exit.Of Mrs Mays marathon summit today to thrash out Brexit plans, he said: Lets see what comes out of Chequers, white smoke, black smoke or no smoke.The European company generates £1.7billion in tax revenues but is considering whether to ditch plans to build aircraft wings at British plants.He revealed today that it is revising its 2018 profits UP from its 2017 predictions, meaning the company is still doing well despite fearful predictions of what could happen after the Brexit vote.The firm said it could move production to China, the US or elsewhere in Europe.The company employs 14,000 people and supports a further 110,000 jobs in its UK supply chain.Airbus has factories in north Wales, Stevenage, Portsmouth and Bristol, allegedly revealed that they delivered private warnings to Theresa May weeks ago.But Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt slapped them down, saying they were making totally inappropriate warnings.He blasted the plane manufacturer for making threats, and urged them to get behind the Prime Minister to make sure a good deal is secured.Other firms such as BMW and Siemens have also raised their own fears about Brexit too.

title: theresa may brexit cabinet meeting chequers
story: The PM faces perhaps the biggest challenge of her career as she tries to unite warring Tories behind her third way customs plan at a summit at her country home, Chequers.Brexiteer ministers are making a last-ditch bid to toughen up Mrs Mays Brexit proposals - and could quit if they fail.The whole Cabinet is staging a 12-hour meeting at Chequers, the PMs country home, to decide on the UKs negotiating stance as they lunch on barbecued chicken, potato salad and scones.Ministers have had their phones taken off them so they cant leak any details or appeal for support from aides and allies.And theyve been warned that if they do end up quitting, they wont be able to get home in their ministerial cars - meaning theyll have to call a taxi instead, or walk miles to the nearest train station.Brexiteer MPs have offered to give them a lift if they do quit - backbencher Peter Bone said: I will be on my way with my car, 4 seats available, guess another couple of cars will be required!Downing Street chiefs hope the PM can emerge late tonight with a fully formed Brexit plan - avoiding the constant sniping which has marked the process so far.Mrs May has angered Brexit backers by proposing a plan which would tie us closely to Brussels rules in a bid to keep trade flowing freely.Half a dozen Eurosceptic ministers held a separate meeting last night to hammer out their own stance.They have told the PM she must keep Britain free to set our own rules on goods - or risk losing out on a bumper trade deal with the US.Jacob Rees-Mogg, who leads a group of Brexiteer backbenchers, said the proposed plan is not Brexit and urged the Cabinet to reject it.Mrs May is braced for senior figures such as Boris Johnson and David Davis to walk out if she cant talk them round.Number 10 has reportedly drawn up plans for an emergency reshuffle so the big beasts can be rapidly replaced if they do resign - with pro-Brexit junior ministers called in to meet the PM, in case they need to be suddenly promoted.But in a boost for the PM, its claimed Boris met David Cameron last night - and the former Prime Minister convinced him he has to back Mrs May.SALADSWheat, beetroot, squash and feta cheeseNew potato salad from the Chequers estateMixed salad leaves from the Chequers estateSummer tomato saladPUDDINGSScones with clotted cream and strawberry jam from the Chequers estateSticky tea loafFruit platterThe PM also won round Trade Secretary Liam Fox, a passionate Brexiteer, by holding one-on-one talks with him in Downing Street after his meeting with the other pro-Leave ministers.The other Brexiteers who are still on the fence include Michael Gove, Penny Mordaunt, Esther McVey and Andrea Leadsom.Mrs Mays de facto deputy David Lidington was sent out to bat for her this morning to persuade wavering ministers they should pledge support.He told the BBCs Today programme: What the PM is wanting to do today is to have a package of proposals that delivers on the referendum vote.We need to do that in a way that minimises the disruption to British jobs, British trade and investment in our country.The New Customs Partnership which would see Britain collect tariffs on behalf of the EU was rejected outright by Brexiteers in the Cabinet.And trade experts warned that the technology needed to make Max Fac - a solution which replaces border controls with electronic monitoring - work wont be ready in time for Brexit.The third way is designed to bring a compromise on customs between the two systems.Britain would scrap the blanket tariffs applied by the EU on most goods coming in from outside Europe, and instead set its own import duties.That is essential in letting the UK strike new trade deals with the rest of the world, with goods coming in tariff-free from countries such as the US.But to enable big companies to continue using supply chains which span the whole of Europe, Britain will continue to apply EU tariffs on around 4 per cent of products - classified as unfinished goods.And European tariffs will also be put on goods which pass through Britains ports on their way to the EU, but never enter the domestic economy.Another measure which would tie the UK closely to the EU is Mrs Mays proposal for full regulatory alignment for goods.That means Britain would copy European regulations on what products can be sold in shops.Its intended to ensure goods can still be imported and exported freely, while avoiding curbs on the services sector which makes up most of our economy.But it could prove controversial because it may hinder trade deals with countries who have different standards for their goods.But ex-minister David Jones warned: This is going to be less than the full Brexit that weve had repeated promises of from the Prime Minister.Nicky Morgan, the former Education Secretary turned pro-EU rebel, said any Cabinet ministers who cant get behind the PM should quit rather than sniping at her internally.She added: What we cannot see is a position that is briefed out tomorrow morning and over the next 48 hours Cabinet ministers begin to undermine and query it.Arriving at the summit today, Chief Whip Julian Smith - who is central to ensuring Mrs Mays plans can make it through the Commons - said he was ready and raring to go.And Liz Truss, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury, revealed she was preparing for the marathon meeting by eating a breakfast of cold pizza.Mr Smiths deputy Chris Pincher last night asked Tory MPs to show public support for the Prime Minister by tweeting out a message of unity ahead of the Chequers talks.But Labour have mocked the summit - sending ministers a Cabinet survival kit including pyjamas, Red Bull, bags of fudge and even a draft resignation letter.INNER CIRCLETheresa May has hatched her Brexit customs plans with the help of a few key aides - and is relying on Cabinet loyalists to give it full-throated backing.Her de facto deputy David Lidington has been crucial to putting together the proposal, and was sent out to defend it on the airwaves this morning.And Chief Whip Julian Smith will be the key figure in forcing the plan through the Commons, against the opposition of Brexiteer MPs.Mrs May can expect to be backed by her closest allies such as Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley and Transport Secretary David Lidington - even though they were on the opposite side of the 2016 referendum.HARDCORE BREXITEERSSeven Brexit-backing ministers have been meeting this week to co-ordinate their response to Mrs Mays proposals.They are led by Boris Johnson and David Davis - the two big beasts whove expressed the most public anger about the possibility of a soft Brexit.Michael Gove, whos been strikingly loyal to the PM so far, is also a member of the group who are threatening to quit over the plan.Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, International Aid Secretary Penny Mordaunt and Andrea Leadsom, the Leader of the House, have also attended the Brexiteer crisis talks.But Trade Secretary Liam Fox has apparently been won over by Mrs May after a late-night chat in Downing Street.SWING VOTERSA key group of ministers - mostly Remain voters who now back Brexit - are thought to be on the fence about Mrs Mays customs compromise.Home Secretary Sajid Javid and Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson have both grown close to the Tory Brexiteers despite voting to stay in the EU two years ago.Treasury Secretary Liz Truss - who also has her eye on the leadership - is keen for Britain to embrace the opportunities of Brexit rather than just enacting damage control.And Natalie Evans, Leader of the House of Lords, is a wildcard as a Brexiteer whos previously been loyal to the PM but may now be running out of patience.PRAGMATIC LOYALISTSThe largest Cabinet grouping is made up of ministers who dont want to rock the boat - and just want to get Brexit over with so the Government can go back to the day job.The ultimate example is Jeremy Hunt, who voted Remain and now says hed change his mind, but is more focussed on boosting the NHS than the details of customs arrangements.Justice Secretary David Gauke, Education Secretary Damian Hinds, Culture Secretary Matt Hancock and Housing Secretary James Brokenshire - all promoted this year - are in the same category.And the Cabinets more junior members - Scotland Secretary David Mundell, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns, Attorney General Jeremy Wright and Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes - are also seen as pragmatic figures who support a Brexit compromise.REMAIN ULTRASThere are just two senior ministers who are dedicated to forcing through the softest Brexit possible.Philip Hammond has become a hate figure among Brexiteers because of his obsession with avoiding short-term disruption to the economy.And Business Secretary Greg Clark is accused of teaming up with large firms to convince Theresa May she needs to stay aligned with European rules.

title: legoland discovery centre birmingham pensioner turned away
story: Yvonne Radcliffe, 74, had travelled alone across Birmingham to visit the new £7m Legoland Discovery Centre, which had opened the day before.But the Lego-loving mums plans were shattered when a security guard told her that adults were barred unless they were with a child.The elderly pensioner was forced to walk nearly a mile back to Birmingham Snow Hill station, before getting a train back to her house.Yvonne, from Hall Green, Birmingham, said: “I couldn’t believe it.Adults make Lego, it’s wonderful. Yet I wasn’t allowed in because I didn’t have a kid with me. You couldn’t make it up really.“I think Lego is fascinating. I’ve watched documentaries on TV and saw it was opening in town.“I told my daughter I fancied a day out to see it, so I got on the train to Snow Hill and walked the rest of the way there.“Once I got there, I walked in and a girl stopped me and said I wasn’t allowed in. She said it’s the rules - I must be accompanied by a child.A spokesman for Legoland said: Legoland Discovery Centres are not theme parks but small, indoor attractions specifically conceived and designed from a child’s perspective to provide safe and fun environments for families with children aged 3-10 to enjoy together.“Many of the key features in the attraction therefore are not suitable or designed for the use of older children or grown adults of any ability - the soft play area, or some of the rides for example.“In order to constantly maintain a welcoming environment in which to play, the centres do not permit entry to any groups of adults, adult couples, or lone adults, regardless of race, gender or ability, who are not accompanied by a young child or children.We will be holding regular adult only evenings linked to every attraction in order to showcase specific attractions within the centre, such as Miniland and including additional events for adults.

title: loch ness monster ness capture plan scotland
story: Officials drew up a set of guidelines on how to protect the new species - including releasing it back into its watery home.The partly serious, partly fun code of practice was written in 2001 by Scottish Natural Heritage, which is funded by the Scottish government.SNH said it will dust off the plan and put it into action should the fabled beast be discovered, reports the BBC.It says officials should take a DNA sample from the monster so scientists can study the creature.Then it should be released back into the Loch with measures put in place to make sure it is not disturbed - as it would be an extremely rare species needing conservation.SNH, which promotes Scottish wildlife and natural habitats, said the 17-year-old code of practice remained relevant today.The organisations Nick Halfhide said: There was a lot of activity on the loch at the time about Nessie.So, partly serious and partly for a bit of fun, we drew up a contingency plan about how we would help Nessie if and when she was found.Some of the lessons we learned then have been relevant when we have reintroduced species like sea eagles, and were used when, a couple of years ago, four new species were found in the sea off the west coast.He added the plan would need to be updated when Nessie is discovered, and local communities and businesses on the shores of Loch Ness would be consulted.The discovery would lead to a boom in tourism to the Loch, which already attracts 400,000 visitors a year from around the world because of the legend.Tales of a monster go back nearly 1,500 years to when Irish missionary St Columba is said to have encountered a beast in the River Ness in 565AD.More recently there have been numerous sightings and pictures - some of which turned out to be faked but others remain unexplained.The creatures appearance has been described as resembling a plesiosaur, an ancient sea monster that died out with the dinosaurs.Earlier this year an international team of scientists gathered environmental DNA from Loch Ness for analysis.The study will aim to confirm what species live there - including possibly any unknown animals that might be lurking in the 754ft depths.A road built alongside the 23-mile lake made it easier for people to visit and sightings of the monster soon followed.The most famous is the surgeons photograph taken by Dr Kenneth Wilson in 1934 and published in the Daily Mail.It fooled people for 40 years and ignited worldwide curiosity in the local myth.But in 1975 the image was exposed as a hoax, created with a wooden head and neck attached to a toy submarine.There have been more than 1,000 sightings since, and a host of documentaries attempting to explain the legend.One of the most convincing photographs showed a brown dinosaur-like hump arching out of the water in 2012.Local tour boat operator George Edwards later admitted he faked it for a bit of fun using a fibreglass prop from a 2011 National Geographic documentary.Last month First Minister Nicola Sturgeon insisted the Loch Ness Monster exists in an interview with ITVs Good Morning Britain.Over the years various efforts have tried and failed to find the beast.In 1987 a £1million exploration called Operation Deepscan used a fleet of 24 boats which used sonar equipment to trawled 23-mile long lake.Nessie must have been hiding because the team came back with nothing.Steve Feltham is recognised by the Guinness Book of Records for the longest continuous Nessie-hunting vigil after moving to Loch Ness from Dorset 27 years ago.He has not seen it yet, but there are ten reported sighting a year on average.In November nine-year-old Sam Knight believed he snapped the monsters fin breaking the surface during a cruise with mum Jo.And last June Australian tourists Peter Jackson and Phillippa Wearne caught a serpentine object on camera while driving along the shore.

title: john lewis bans shopper epilepsy every uk store
story: Paul Chambers, 54, from Solihull, West Midlands, suffers from epilepsy and needed the goods to be visually perfect.Mr Chambers had spent £900 for the Samsung and Panasonic televisions he bought from the store over a three year period.But he recalls experiencing a number of problems with all of them, including ghosting, calibrating and pixelating.John Lewis told Mr Chambers they were ending their business relationship with him because they were unable to meet [his] service needs and could not meet [his] expectations, BirminghamLive reported.Mr Chambers said: Every time I have taken them back the staff have been very friendly so I was shocked to receive this letter.They have banned me from every John Lewis in the country and I cant buy anything off them online.The letter read: In light of your recent enquiries we now feel it necessary, and prudent, to terminate our business relationship with you.This decision applies to all John Lewis Department stores, JohnLewis and Waitrose. This will take immediate effect.Please be advised we shall not process any orders you attempt to place by telephone or online channels.We have taken this decision due to our firm belief that we are unable to meet your service needs, nor do we believe our range of products will meet your expectations.We would therefore ask you not to visit the Solihull store or any other John Lewis branch.If you do we shall ask you to leave immediately, we would not wish to embarrass you in this way so we would ask you to comply with this request.Mr Chambers said his friend kindly lent him his TV, but he would have liked to returned to the store, to purchase another.A John Lewis spokesperson later defended their decision, and said: Were sorry to hear Mr Chambers is disappointed.We always want to deliver the very best service for our customers, so we never take this kind of action lightly or without investigation.

title: top tories are already competing to take over from theresa may if the pm is brought down over brexit
story: As the Prime Minister embarks on a marathon summit to thrash out Brexit with her Cabinet today - many of them are already mulling their own strategies for how they could seize the top job, should she fall.In the corridors of Westminster plotting is already afoot, and many ministers and MPs have been going over what to do if the Prime Minister cant get the Government through the next crucial few months.Mrs May faces a tough fight to keep her Cabinet, backbenchers and European colleagues from tearing chunks out of each other.And theres every risk that her precarious position, with a slim majority in Parliament - could topple over.Last year furious Tories said she was just a caretaker Prime Minister after she lost their election, so who could be in the battle to replace her? The Foreign Secretary is still a firm favourite to take over from Mrs May if she quits or is forced out of No10.One of the main faces of the Brexit campaign and still popular with the public, Boris hasnt been shy on making big interventions on our EU exit in the last year.But he chickened out of voting against Heathrow last month by fleeing overseas - leading many to ask whether hes lost some of his bullish bravado. Since he took over from Amber Rudd following the Windrush debacle, Sajid Javid has been making his mark on the Home Office.The new Home Secretary - one of the great offices of state - could be one to keep an eye on. Leader of the backbench Brexiteers, Mr Rees-Moggs popularity among the public has somewhat worn off in recent months.But hes still in a hugely influential role as head of the European Research Group, and has respect among many of his fellow MPs.Hes also reportedly seeking out a PR firm - possibly to help convert his supporters into votes in a future leadership race.However, hes never held a ministerial job and jumping straight to becoming Prime Minister would be a pretty big leap - even for the Mogg, who says he doesnt want the job anyway. The man has made a pretty impressive comeback since stabbing Boris Johnson in the back after the EU referendum - by announcing he would abandon his mate and go for the leadership alone.Since being brought back into the Cabinet hes made headlines with a string of well-received environmental policies - from crackdowns on puppy farming to eco-friendly coffee cups.Dont underestimate what this Brexiteer is capable of. The Chief Secretary to the Treasury has been making waves in recent weeks with her intervention in the tax debate.She made a bold speech saying the Tories shouldnt be just banning things and raising taxes in a way that is unConservative to try and compete with Jeremy Corbyns Labour.That followed a huge digital drive to get more followers on her Twitter and Instagram.Critics said she was making a naked bid for No10 - that would be quite something indeed. The Brexit Secretary has ruffled feathers by dropping hints he could quit his role over Mrs Mays strategy in recent weeks.After a bitter row about customs relations with Brussels, the ex-SAS fighter has been knuckling down and helping to deliver our EU exit strategy.This week he held crunch talks with the PM over her too soft Brexit plans, showing hes not afraid to stand up for what he wants, but would be be able to bring a warring cabinet together afterwards? Despite the endless flak that comes with being Health Secretary, Mr Hunt fought to cling on to his job during Mrs Mays last reshuffle, leading many to think that this man has a bit more steel that was first thought.And hes managed to win more cash for the NHS as the health service marks its 70th birthday this year.Despite his poor public image, this Remainer turned Brexiteer could be a key uniting candidate in any such leadership race.The Defence Secretary, though new to being a minister, is also being seen as positioning himself ahead of a possible leadership election.Hes been battling the Treasury very publicly for more money ever since he took over from Sir Michael Fallon at the end of last year.And he was even reported to have said he could bring down Mrs May in a bitter row over funding just last month.But his weedy comments telling Russia to shut up and go away may put people off the idea hes a strong enough leader to get Britain through Brexit.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesia man flogged public sharia law
story: After being led out in front of a crowd at a stadium, he was whipped by a masked man wielding a cane.Other images show kneeling women, accused of being prostitutes, grimacing in pain as they too are whipped in front of onlookers.The savage beatings happened in the city of Lhokseumawe in Aceh province - despite moves earlier this year for the punishments to be given in prison.Aceh is the only province in the worlds most populous Muslim-majority country that imposes sharia law.Suspects can be flogged for a range of offences including gambling, drinking alcohol, having gay sex or an extramarital relationship.The man was beaten for violating the states strict sharia code - though the exact nature of his offence is not known.The group are among several to be punished under Acehs strict religious law since it was adopted in 2001 as part of a deal with the central government.In January, an Indonesian Christian was flogged for selling alcohol in the province at the tip of Sumatra island.Around 98 per cent of Acehs five million residents are Muslims and subject to its religious laws.Non-Muslims who have committed an offence that violates both national and religious laws can choose to be prosecuted under either system.The group are far from the first to face such a public and humiliating punishment.Christians and other non-Muslims sometimes choose a flogging to avoid a lengthy court process and jail term.

title: mike pompeo north korea kim jong un elton john rocket man cd
story: Mike Pompeo will reportedly present Kim with the disc along with a letter from Donald Trump, who branded the dictator little rocket man last year.Trump - who has allegedly signed the CD - gave Kim the nickname as the US and North Korea were on the brink of nuclear catastrophe.Following a series of North Korean nuclear tests, the US leader famously threatened the secret communist state with fire and fury like the world has never seen.Pompeo is visiting Pyongyang as part of a follow-up meeting set-up in the wake of the successful Singapore summit last month.South Korean newspaper Chosun Ilbo said Trump and Kim had even spoke about the sobriquet during their historic meeting.Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, left, shakes hands with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un during a meeting at Workers Party of Korea headquarters in Pyongyang, North Korea last monthIts understood Kim told the US president he had never heard the 1972 hit, so Trump sent Pompeo on his way armed with a copy.He arrived in Pyongyang today and said he hopes to fill in details of how to dismantle the Norths nuclear programme.He also plans to build on momentum generated during the Trump-Kim summit.According to US department of states spokeswoman Heather Nauert, Pompeo told reporters on his plane: “Our leaders made commitments at the Singapore summit on the complete denuclearisation ofNorth Korea and outlined what a transformed US-DPRK relationship could look like. “On this trip I’m seeking to fill in some details on these commitments and continue the momentum towards implementation of what the two leaders promised each other and the world.“I expect that the DPRK is ready to do the same.”In an earlier tweet Pompeo said Trump believes Kim wants a different, brighter future for North Koreans.

title: bin lorry sinks into tarmac as uk swelters in heatwave
story: The fire brigade tweeted: "He stayed calm and called 999. Thankfully he was wearing his granddad's @drmartens!"The UK is enjoying a heatwave that forecasters predict will continue through most of July following a drier than usual June.Temperatures could reach as high as 33C in parts of London and the South East on Friday, equalling the record for 2018 which was felt in Porthmadog, Wales, on 28 June. The Met Office has recorded temperatures of 29C in London, while Manchester was slightly cooler at 25C.Birmingham in the Midlands recorded a temperature of 26C, while parts of the North East were much cooler at 18C.Sky News weather producer Joanna Robinson said: "There is only about a 30% chance of reaching 33C today."Then it cools off from the north next week, with highs in the south more like the mid-twenties by Wednesday."Met Office weather forecaster Emma Salter said: "There's no let up in sight in terms of the dry weather and high temperatures through the week."It's pretty much dry across the board and no sign of rain." She continued: "From Monday or Tuesday the really high temperatures will start to gradually come down, but it will still be in the high 20s so it will be 'less hot' rather than cooler."Ms Salter added that Scotland might see some rain in the coming days, but the rest of Britain is expected to stay dry until the middle of July.She added: "There will be some rain perhaps, but then it looks quite settled again through the rest of the month."Storms had been predicted for Friday earlier in the week but Ms Salter said these were now looking "very unlikely" and had been removed from the forecast.

title: friends of cameron deny worst of both worlds claim over mays brexit plan
story: But friends of the former PM later came out to deny this was the case, adding Mr Cameron "always thought a compromise would be needed" over the terms of the UK's departure from the EU.Sir Craig Oliver, Mr Cameron's director of communications during his time in Downing Street, wrote on Twitter: "Claims that @David_Cameron thinks @theresa_may's position is the "worst of both worlds" are wrong."He has always understood compromise will be necessary. It's also wrong to claim he sees himself as 'the father of Brexit'. Why would that be true when he fought it tooth and nail?" Mr Cameron called the EU vote and campaigned for Remain. He announced his resignation the morning after voters backed Brexit by a margin of 52% to 48% in June 2016.The meeting comes as his successor gathers her cabinet at her Chequers country retreat in a bid to agree on what they want the UK's post-Brexit relationship with the EU to look like.But there are vastly differing views on how closely, if at all, the UK should mirror Brussels' rules and regulations when it comes to issues such as trade and customs. Leavers say sticking too close to them would not represent the will expressed by voters in the 2016 referendum to "take back control", while Remainers argue going too far the other way would lead to chaos for businesses.The plans being considered by ministers could see the UK keep a "common rule book" with the EU for all goods, including agricultural and food products.It has also been claimed that Downing Street is prepared to concede that plans to align the UK with EU regulations in this respect would make a free trade deal with the US unlikely - something Number 10 later dismissed as "categorically untrue".   Speaking ahead of the summit, which will last well into Friday evening, Mrs May said the government had "an opportunity and a duty" to reach an agreement."We want a deal that allows us to deliver the benefits of Brexit - taking control of our borders, laws and money and by signing ambitious new trade deals with countries like the US, Australia and New Zealand," she said."This is about agreeing an approach that delivers decisively on the verdict of the British people - an approach that is in the best interests of the UK and the EU, and crucially, one that commands the support of the public and parliament." But the proposals revealed thus far have not gone down well with eurosceptic Tory MPs - and sparked speculation about whether there could be ministerial resignations.Lucy Allen said simply that "this is not Brexit", while Andrea Jenkyns said Brexit-backing MPs "cannot support any deal that restricts our trade with other countries".She warned "from what we are hearing, (we are) prepared to vote against this".One source said Leave-supporting backbenchers do not even think the PM's plans will end up being put to MPs because "Boris and David aren't having it". Brexiteers have received support from an unlikely quarter, with former deputy PM and staunch Remainer Nick Clegg tweeting: "I hate to say this, but Brexiters would be right to reject PM's plan."Dual EU/UK tariffs would create vast red tape, smugglers would boom,Parliament would be humiliated. MPs would rubber stamp goods/agri rules from Brussels - right to refuse would never be used as costs too high."Better to put this costly, bureaucratic, unworkable proposal out of its misery ASAP. Whatever Brexit means, it can't be this." On the eve of the showdown, Brexit-backing ministers held their own private talks in Westminster.Mr Johnson, David Davis, Michael Gove, Esther McVey, Penny Mordaunt, Andrea Leadsom and Liam Fox met at the Foreign Office.Dr Fox, the international trade secretary, then spent 50 minutes at Number 10 with the PM.A Downing Street source said Dr Fox had been "for a chat" and dismissed speculation he might resign.

title: i didnt find it funny ariana grande responds to fiances manchester bombing joke
story: The 24-year-old comedian, best known for his sketches on Saturday Night Live, is alleged to have said that Grande must realise how famous she is because "Britney Spears didn't have a terror attack at her concert".Twenty-two people were killed by Salman Abedi after he detonated an explosive device in the foyer of Manchester Arena shortly after Grande's concert on 22 May last year.Davidson is understood to have made the joke during a stand-up routine several months after the attack. He was not in a relationship with Grande at the time.The fan tweeted: "I respect Ariana and I want her to be happy and everything, but she was just broken after the Manchester bombing, so I don't know why she is still with Pete, like yeah he made that joke a while ago, but like it's not funny, it's just rude. This is my opinion."   Replying to the tweet, Grande wrote: "this has been v tough & conflicting on my heart. he uses comedy to help ppl feel better ab how f-ed up things in this world are. we all deal w trauma differently. I of course didn't find it funny. it was months ago & his intention wasn't/ is never malicious but it was unfortunate".While Davidson has not publicly responded to the backlash, his representative previously said: "Pete is a comedian. No subject is off limits & that includes jokes about his father & 9/11."Davidson's father, who was a New York City firefighter, died in service during the September 11 attacks. title: so whats in theresa mays brexit plan
story: :: What is the PM proposing?We haven't been told everything, but the broad outlines of what Mrs May wants to put forward have started to emerge.Papers circulated to ministers are reported to recommend that the UK should keep a "common rule book" with the EU for all goods, including agricultural and food products.It was claimed that Downing Street was prepared to concede that plans to align the UK with EU regulations in this respect would make a free trade deal with the US unlikely.However, Number 10 later came out and said such talk was "categorically untrue".US commerce secretary Wilbur Ross has warned in the past that a failure by Britain to move away from EU food safety rules in areas such as GM crops and chlorinated chicken would be an impediment to a successful trade agreement.:: What about services?The plan is to diverge from EU rules and regulations in this area, with an acknowledgement that this is likely to result in reduced access for UK-based companies to European markets.However, it is hoped that this will be offset by growth in markets around the world. :: How does Mrs May intend to sort out the customs issue?With a so-called "third way".The PM's proposed "facilitated customs arrangement" would see technology being used to work out where goods arriving into the UK will ultimately end up.This would mean the correct tariff could be paid - either at the EU or UK rate.Mrs May came up with the plan in a bid to solve the thorny issue of Britain's post-Brexit customs system, after two previous options provoked opposition from different factions of her cabinet.Brussels also gave the plans - a "customs partnership" and "maximum facilitation" - a short shrift.However, her own Brexit secretary is reported to be opposed to the plan, labelling it "unworkable". :: What has the PM said about all of this?Mrs May has told her ministers that they have a "great opportunity", but also a "duty" - a pointed reference perhaps to the need to suck it up and fall into line.:: That's all well and good, but how has this gone down among Tory MPs?Among Brexiteers? Not well at all.Eurosceptic former cabinet minister Owen Paterson said the plans would represent a "complete breach of Theresa May's manifesto commitment, reconfirmed to me at PMQs yesterday [Wednesday], to leave (the) single market, customs union and European Court of Justice".He added: "We would be out of Europe but still run by Europe."Lucy Allen said simply that "this is not Brexit", while Andrea Jenkyns said Brexit-backing MPs "cannot support any deal that restricts our trade with other countries".She warned "from what we are hearing, (we are) prepared to vote against this".One source said Leave-supporting backbenchers do not even think the PM's plans will end up being put to MPs because "Boris and David aren't having it". :: Will there be any resignations?It feels like we are reaching a tipping point. Since the referendum, we've seen the can being kicked down the road, the fudge reheated, the thorny issues tossed into the long grass.But now the government has to agree a common position in a bid to move forward in the negotiations with Brussels.Something has got to give, surely?Sky News understands that six Brexiteer ministers, led by Boris Johnson and David Davis, will tell the PM her plan is "not acceptable", with Sajid Javid, Gavin Williamson and Alun Cairns set to back them.Westminster is abuzz with resignation speculation, but will ministers quit over a plan that could very well be rejected by Brussels?Sky's senior political correspondent Beth Rigby says the expectation is that Mrs May will "scrape through".She reports there is a lack of appetite among ministers for a leadership contest that would be sparked by such a mortal blow to the PM's authority. :: What will happen next?Provided Mrs May can get an agreement through, a white paper setting out the government's Brexit blueprint will be published next week.The PM then wants talks with Europe to "intensify and accelerate".

title: chequers brexit summit theresa braced
story: NewsChequers Brexit summit: Theresa May braced for ambush and resignations as top Tories descend on 12-hour country showdownTop Tories have arrived at her 16th Century country retreat in their sleek ministerial cars - and could be leaving in a taxi close to midnight&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter10:50, 6 JUL 2018Updated13:36, 6 JUL 2018NewsTop Tories were arriving in sleek ministerial cars - and could be leaving in a taxi (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is braced for an ambush and resignations as Cabinet ministers descend on Chequers in a showdown that will make or break her premiership. Tory Leave-backers held dramatic crisis talks last night just hours before the Prime Minister summoned ministers to agree a 'softer' Brexit plan at a marathon 12-hour clash. Top Tories arrived at her 16th Century country retreat this morning in their sleek ministerial cars - and could be leaving after dark in a taxi. A No10 source warned the Prime Minister had already drawn up an emergency reshuffle plan if she's hit with mass resignations by Brexiteers - and those who quit must take a taxi the 40 miles back to London. Until then they are being locked in and surrendering their mobile phones to prevent leaks. The source told the Politico website: A select number of ego-driven, leadership-dominated Cabinet ministers need to support the PM in the best interests of the UK.  Or their spots will be taken by a talented new generation of MPs who will sweep them away. Tory Leaver Peter Bone offered to give a lift to fleets of resigning Brexiteers to save them the taxi fare. I will be on my way with my car, 4 seats available, guess another couple of cars will be required! he tweeted.   International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt was one of the earliest arrivals at Chequers for the all-day Cabinet session. Justice Secretary David Gauke and Transport Secretary Chris Grayling were both spotted being driven in. And Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss inexplicably had pizza for breakfast.   Young Remain voters held aloft a banner declaring your Brexit deal screws our future this morning outside the PM's Buckinghamshire bolthole. But furious Brexiteer Tories fear the 120-page plan will not be 'hard Brexit' enough.  They erupted into fury after it emerged the White Paper, which promises alignment with EU rules on goods, could make a trade deal with the US much harder. Theresa May's deputy David Lidington today denied a trade deal with the US would be impossible - and said the claims were pretty selective leaks of gobbets from Cabinet papers. But he did not deny they were accurate - saying only they were misquoted.  Instead he said: It’s like one of these theatre reviews that says this was not a brilliant performance and it goes up outside as 'brilliant'. Mr Lidington said he was “confident the Cabinet will have a “concrete position that everyone will be able to sign up to” when the summit ends at 10pm. But seven top-level Brexiteers including Boris Johnson and Michael Gove were spotted meeting last night in what is expected to be a bid to harden up the plans. Boris Johnson also reportedly met former Prime Minister David Cameron last night - with one source claiming the pair agreed Mrs May's deal was the worst of all worlds. Want to keep up to date with the latest from Westminster? Sign up to our newsletter to receive regular news, expert comment and analysis from our Mirror Politics team.  Theresa May has put off key decisions about whether to choose 'hard' or 'soft' Brexit, far or close links with the EU, for months due to Tory splits. Now she must make hard choices with just weeks of negotiation time left before the EU's October deadline. The key split is over how customs rules should work after Brexit. Mrs May had put forward two options - but both were rejected. Now she has put forward a third way, known as a Facilitated Customs Arrangement, that would let Britain set its own tariffs on goods in exchange for closely following EU standards. Brexiteer ex-minister David Jones said Theresa May's deal looked not very good at all.  He warned the red lines of leaving the customs union, single market and jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice would be breached by what is being proposed today. But Remain-backing former Cabinet minister Nicky Morgan said ministers who don't fall in line should resign. If somebody said 'I just cannot live with this, this is not what I want' then yes, I think that they would have to think about their position, she told the BBC. Tory Mayor of the West Midlands Andy Street urged ministers who refuse to get behind Theresa May’s Brexit strategy to “get off the bus”. Mrs May added: This is about agreeing an approach that delivers decisively on the verdict of the British people – an approach that is in the best interests of the UK and the EU, and crucially, one that commands the support of the public and Parliament. Labour issued a mocking 'Cabinet survival kit' with a can to kick down the road - and a packet of fudge for if Theresa May continues to fudge her options.  Shadow Brexit minister Jenny Chapman said: Tory infighting over Brexit has got so serious Labour has been left with little choice but to try and offer ministers a helping hand before this latest peace summit. “But there is a serious point to this. Every single day the Government wastes arguing with itself puts jobs and the economy at risk and increases the chances of the UK crashing out without a deal. No deal would be the worst possible outcome for our country. The EU has a 'customs union'. This means the 28 states trade EU goods for free - and set an equal tariff on non-EU goods. For example, US car imports to the EU are taxed at 10%. Being in this customs union helps the UK, because the EU is our biggest trading partner and it prevents lorry checks at the border. Theresa May wants the UK to leave it because otherwise, Britain will have to follow EU rules and cannot strike trade deals around the world. But this creates a huge row with Brussels - and a headache of how to keep the border open between Northern Ireland (UK) and the Republic (EU). Britain was looking at two options: Customs partnership: Liked by Remainers, branded idiotic by Brexiteers. Britain would stick close to EU tariffs on imports and collect them on behalf of the EU. If the UK tariff is lower than the EU one, firms would be able to reclaim the difference. Maximum Facilitation - 'Max Fac': Liked by Brexiteers, but could cost firms &pound20bn a year. Would keep the UK separate from Brussels rules. High-tech tracking devices would try to cut bureaucracy. E.g. Trusted” firms could pay tariffs at regular intervals, not every time they cross a border. Both options were rejected so now Tories are reportedly considering this 'third way': Facilitated Customs Arrangement: A compromise. The UK would leave blanket EU tariffs, allowing us to set our own import duties. But if goods are unfinished or destined to end up in the EU, Britain would still collect EU tariffs on Brussels' behalf. And crucially, the UK would keep many of the same rules - regulatory alignment - as the EU on standards of goods.

title: entire tory cabinet refuse meet
story: NewsEvery single Tory Cabinet minister refuses to meet young campaigners who want to stop BrexitEXCLUSIVE: Anti-Brexit group Our Future Our Choice sent invitations to every member of the Cabinet - and got a clean sweep of rejections&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter17:14, 6 JUL 2018Updated17:19, 6 JUL 2018NewsThe anti-Brexit group Our Future Our Choice sent invitations to every Cabinet minister (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Tory Cabinet has been accused of ignoring young people's fears over Brexit after every single minister rejected a request for a meeting.  The anti-Brexit group Our Future Our Choice sent invitations to every Cabinet minister except Theresa May herself. But they were either outright rejected, in most cases, or repeatedly ignored, in the rest, by every single one. In one case Brexiteer Liam Fox's staff admitted there'd been a deafening silence when trying to fix a date adding: Dr Fox’s schedule is a nightmare. Activist Tessa Milligan, 20, from Hemel Hempstead, told the Mirror: To have flat out rejections or be completely ignored by the entire Cabinet is pretty demoralising. She added: Young people don't have the best links to government.  Since the referendum it feels like we have been completely written out of any debate about Brexit. The 'OFOC' group claims Brexit is a disaster and should be democratically stopped. It has close links to other well-funded 'People's Vote' campaigns including Open Britain and Best For Britain. Not content with being ignored, OFOC staged a protest outside Theresa May's Chequers summit today. In an open letter to the PM, the group wrote: We can only infer from your Cabinet’s wholesale refusal to meet and discuss your Brexit deal with us that you and your colleagues know what we fear: your deal will deeply damage our future. The fact not a single open invitation was accepted sends a loud, clear message to young people across the UK that our thoughts about Brexit are not worth enough to be heard or acknowledged by your government.  While activists talked to police officers outside, inside ministers were furiously at work trying to thrash out a compromise Brexit plan. So close - yet so far. We've seen the email replies from Cabinet ministers' offices giving their various excuses for not turning up. Here's what they said. What the activists were told  Alun Cairns NO REPLY Baroness Evans Unfortunately, the Lords Leader is unable to attend due to commiting already to another event at the same time. Boris Johnson The Foreign Secretary has considered your invitation and would have liked to accept regrettably he is unable to do so due to diary pressure. Brandon Lewis NO REPLY  Chris Grayling Unfortunately, as I am sure you will appreciate, Chris gets a large volume of speaking invitations and it is not possible for him to accept them all. Damian Hinds The Secretary of State was most pleased to be invited to OFOC. However, diary commitments mean that he is unable to at this time. David Davis NO REPLY David Gauke Many thanks for your kind invitation to meet. David regrets he cannot attend on this occasion. David Lidington  The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Minister for the Cabinet Office, the Rt Hon David Lidington MP was very grateful for the Invitation to meet with Our Future Our Choice unfortunately due to his current diary commitments and travel schedule, he will be unable to meet with Our Future Our Choice presidents.   David Mundell Rt Hon David Mundell MP has asked me to thank you for the invitation. Unfortunately Mr Mundell is unable to attend due to ministerial and constituency diary commitments. Esther McVey Unfortunately, given the pressure on the diary, both in the constituency and the Department, Esther doesn’t feel able to commit to speaking at the event. She would not like to commit and then have to let you down nearer the event. Gavin Williamson  Thank you for your email to speak to Our Future Our Choice. Unfortunately, due to a ministerial commitments, the Secretary of State, Gavin Williamson , is unable to attend.  Greg Clark The Secretary of State was grateful for your request, but is fortunate enough to receive a great number of meeting and invitation requests, so regrettably, he cannot accept as many as he would like. James Brokenshire James Brokenshire has asked me to thank you for your invitation. However, he regrets that due to extensive commitments he is unable to accept. Jeremy Hunt Regrettably due to pressure on his diary, Jeremy is unable to accept your kind invitation on this occasion.  Karen Bradley Karen has asked me to thank you for the email but I am afraid she is not able to accept the invitation at the moment. Liam Fox I have sent half a dozen emails to [ANONYMOUS AIDE] since you first contacted. There has been a deafening silence. Dr Fox’s schedule is a nightmare. We have no Fridays available as the only ones there are have to be allocated to the constituency. Most Saturdays if he is in the UK, he is already booked up to speak around the country. I don’t really think he is a good proposition for you at all. Matt Hancock He would love to be able to help, but sadly he does not think that this will be possible. Matt’s diary is heavily committed over the coming months, so I am afraid that he is unable to accept. He appreciates you thinking of him though and hopes that the event is a great success.

title: how tell ministers want flounce
story: NewsopinionHow to tell which ministers want to flounce out of today's crunch Chequers summitChequers has a long drive, a very long one. It is not designed for flouncing. But there's an easy way to tell who wants to bolt it, writes Nigel Nelson&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNigel NelsonPolitical Editor13:28, 6 JUL 2018Updated15:24, 6 JUL 2018NewsopinionWill Environment Secretary Michael Gove be one of those to flounce out? (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAll the speculation about the Chequers Cabinet summit today is over which ministers will flounce out with the smart money on Boris Johnson. So here’s your guide to flouncing so you can be ahead of the game. Choosing the PM’s Buckinghamshire country retreat instead of No10 was a masterstroke by the PM. Flouncing out of No10 is a simple business. You tell Mrs May you’re quitting, bowl out of the famous black door, and within seconds you’re in the London streets.  Chequers is 40 miles away from the capital, and potential flouncers have been told they won’t be allowed to use their ministerial cars to take them there if they resign. Legging it is not much of an option either. Chequers has a long drive, a very long one. It is not designed for flouncing.  You will get to the end of it drenched in sweat and feeling thoroughly humiliated. And then, still dripping away, you must wait for a taxi.  But if you have forgotten to take a card for the local Aston’s Taxis cab firm, helpfully placed on the Chequers sideboard for such eventualities, you must walk all the way back up the drive again to get one. International Trade Secretary Liam Fox is now off the PM’s flouncing list, as was Environment Secretary Michael Gove last night and then back on it this morning. You can never tell with the Gover as he is adept at changing sides at the last minute.

title: real story whats going chequers
story: NewsopinionThe real story of what's going on at the Chequers Brexit summitIt's coming home, it's coming home, it's coming - sanity's coming home&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist13:56, 6 JUL 2018Updated14:59, 6 JUL 2018Newsopinion&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDown the mile-long gravelled drive of Chequers they come, a fleet of shiny, chauffeur driven cars each with a sound system playing Three Lions. He's coming home, he's coming home, he's coming, Boris is coming home, hums Boris Johnson under his breath, while WhatsApping his co-conspirators about threatening mass resignations and forcing the Prime Minister to do his bidding. Theresa, meanwhile, is in the drawing room with a length of lead pipe and wondering how many times she'd have to headbutt it to end this hell. For two years now the Conservative Party has been healing Brexit division in the country by demonstrating the same sort of unity you get from putting an atom bomb in a mincer. A huge burst of energy and noise, followed by proto-particles pinging around randomly and leaving behind a toxic goo that'd still make you gag 4.5billion years later.  Despite the fact the Tories haven't been able to reconcile their stance on Europe for 44 years, some bright spark set a deadline for them to have a Brexit plan by next March. And so as the clock ticks down and the ruling party is fed slowly into the metal teeth of time, they wriggle and writhe in a desperate bid to ensure that on the other side of the grinder lies a land of milk and honey. It's a bit like watching people invent their own idea of heaven while having their limbs sliced off an inch at a time. Life without fingernails is fine, elbows are ungodly, ONLY THE DEVIL NEEDS SHOULDERS!   In normal political times, the thought of a Prime Minister needing to hold a summit and cut a deal with their own Cabinet would be evidence of an imminent general election. In Year 0002 Anno Brexitus, it's just another Friday. Albeit one of a finite, and diminishing, number of Fridays available for this sort of economy-shattering farting about. For days and weeks now more than half a dozen of the Cabinet have been having secret 8am meetings in Boris Johnson's office, and coincidentally over the same period have come a series of leaks about ministers who hate the PM's plans, ministers who want the PM's job, and a number of excuses about why pro-Brexit groups breaking electoral law to get a Brexit vote does not, in any way, mean Brexit is undemocratic. It's still the democratic will of the people, it seems, even if the people's democracy was broken first. And now here they come. Boris, Gove, Davis - men who all tried and failed to be Prime Minister, and are now trying to be the men in charge of the Prime Minister. And there's the Prime Minister. A woman given the impossible task of keeping egotists happy, while having no means to achieve it.  Are we all here? Has Boris turned up or is he on a convenient foreign trip in order to avoid reality, again? Ah, there you are behind me. Sit where I can see you please, and hand that ivory-handled dagger to 007. Mr Bond, please guard the door and see that Laura Kuenssberg can't get in. Right, everyone, thank you for coming to this meeting of St Theresa's church fete committee, I mean Brexit war summit, whoops wrong paperwork! That's tomorrow. I hope you all left your mobiles in reception as requested and that the cable ties attaching you to the chairs are not chafing too badly, but you see it's pretty clear I can't trust any of you c***s not to leak like that vomiting girl in The Exorcist so these are the lengths to which you have driven me. Now, the problem before us is this. The people have voted to Leave the EU and if we do that they'll lose their jobs, be foraging out of skips and actively go out looking for Novichok-laced fag butts in order to end their hell, for which we will be blamed. Every business big and small will be utterly f***ed if we impose border controls so we have to come to a customs and trading deal with the EU which allows things to continue much as they are now, and if we do that the editor of the Daily Mail and quite a few of the people tied to that sofa will says it's not Brexit and bring down our government. F** BUSINESS!  I don't doubt you've tried, Boris, but you're not helping. Added to this there is a broad agreement we must control immigration, for which we need a hard border at all our ports of entry, and if we have a hard border in Northern Ireland we can wave goodbye to Northern Ireland. If that happens, it will also not be Brexit because it will in fact be 'ohf***sh*t', or at least that's what the Queen said when she explained how it feels to be racked in the Tower. So here we are. We cannot f** business, but the people have told us to do something that will. If we obey the will of the people, they'll blame us rather than themselves. title: tory government no clue how
story: NewsTory government has 'no clue' how to do Brexit without 'severe harm' declares Airbus chiefTom Enders' warning comes as EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier complained there were "still too few answers" - despite offering Britain an olive branch.&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter14:00, 6 JUL 2018NewsThe latest warning to Theresa May came from the aerospace giant (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory government has 'no clue' how to do Brexit without causing significant harm to Britain, he head of Airbus has said.  Tom Enders' warning came as EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier complained there were still too few answers - despite offering Britain an olive branch.  The twin interventions were made while the Tory Cabinet were holed up in a 12-hour summit at Chequers to thrash out the UK's Brexit plan. Mr Enders, chief executive of the European plane giant, said: The sun is shining brightly on the UK, the English team is progressing towards the final, the RAF is preparing to celebrate its centenary. And Her Majesty's Government still has no clue, no consensus on how to execute Brexit without severe harm.   Airbus, which has 14,000 UK staff, triggered a backlash in the Tory party last month after threatening to pull out of the country in a no deal Brexit.  Mr Enders said today: Rest assured we are taking first preparations as we speak in order to be able to mitigate consequences from whatever Brexit scenario may follow. Make no mistake - Brexit, in whatever form, soft or hard, light or clean or whatever you call it, will be damaging for the industry, for our industry, for other industries and damaging for the UK whatever the outcome will be. Meanwhile the EU today told Britain there were still too many unanswered questions over Brexit.  Brussels' chief negotiator Michel Barnier said: In the Brexit negotiations, there are still too many questions and too few answers. But he also stretched out an olive branch to Britain - as long as Theresa May gives some ground.  Mr Barnier said: As the European Council has made clear, we are ready - I am ready - to adapt our offer should the UK's red lines change. Time is short. We need to quickly have realistic and workable solutions and obviously we look forward to the UK's White Paper. The UK's proposals will facilitate both the UK's internal political debate and negotiation with us. Our objective has always been to find an agreement with the UK, not against the UK. The EU has a 'customs union'. This means the 28 states trade EU goods for free - and set an equal tariff on non-EU goods. For example, US car imports to the EU are taxed at 10%. Being in this customs union helps the UK, because the EU is our biggest trading partner and it prevents lorry checks at the border. Theresa May wants the UK to leave it because otherwise, Britain will have to follow EU rules and cannot strike trade deals around the world. But this creates a huge row with Brussels - and a headache of how to keep the border open between Northern Ireland (UK) and the Republic (EU). Britain was looking at two options: Customs partnership: Liked by Remainers, branded idiotic by Brexiteers. Britain would stick close to EU tariffs on imports and collect them on behalf of the EU. If the UK tariff is lower than the EU one, firms would be able to reclaim the difference. Maximum Facilitation - 'Max Fac': Liked by Brexiteers, but could cost firms &pound20bn a year. Would keep the UK separate from Brussels rules. High-tech tracking devices would try to cut bureaucracy. E.g. Trusted” firms could pay tariffs at regular intervals, not every time they cross a border. Both options were rejected so now Tories are reportedly considering this 'third way': Facilitated Customs Arrangement: A compromise. The UK would leave blanket EU tariffs, allowing us to set our own import duties. But if goods are unfinished or destined to end up in the EU, Britain would still collect EU tariffs on Brussels' behalf. And crucially, the UK would keep many of the same rules - regulatory alignment - as the EU on standards of goods.

title: what chequers welcome prime ministers
story: NewsWhat is Chequers? Inside the Prime Minister's lavish country house hosting her Brexit summitOne aide warned ‘blood on the carpet is no bad thing' - and this lavish mansion wouldn't be out of place in a murder mystery&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByEuan O'Connor12:56, 6 JUL 2018Updated14:53, 6 JUL 2018NewsIn the shadow of the Chiltern Hills nestles the Prime Minister's residence Chequers (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May is today holding a much-anticipated crunch meeting with her Cabinet at Chequers on the UK’s Brexit plan. One aide to the Prime Minister warned ‘blood on the carpet is no bad thing’ as she faces the threat of a mass resignation. It's an apt phrase - because Chequers wouldn't be out of place in a murder mystery. Ministers have been told that their phones will be confiscated on arrival at the luxurious Buckinghamshire retreat to avoid leaks. And between wood-panelled walls and sumptous grounds, talks are expected to last late into the night.  The PM’s country retreat has played host to many important talks in the past, including last year when Mrs May met with senior aides and pollsters to discuss the pros and cons of calling the snap election that resulted in her losing her majority. But what is Chequers and why is it being used for these crucial talks? Here’s everything you need to know…  Chequers is a luxurious country house found just outside of Great Missenden in Buckinghamshire, about 41 miles from 10 Downing Street. One theory is it is named after the chequer trees that grow on the estate. It’s not the biggest of stately homes, with just 10 bedrooms (Buckingham Palace has 240) but it has vast swathes of land - around 1,500 acres are at the owner’s disposal. It also features a huge art collection, with 190 pieces dating from the early sixteenth century to a 1937 piece by none other than Winston Churchill.  It was built in its present form in 1565 by the High Sheriff of Buckinghamshire, William Hawtrey, though historians say there has been a manor house on the site since the Roman era. The house has been connected to many important events and personalities in British history. One of its owners was a grandson of the puritanical Lord Protector, Oliver Cromwell. Why does Theresa May get to stay there?  Chequers has been at the disposal of the Prime Minister of the day since it was gifted to the nation by its then-owners Lord and Lady Lee in 1917. The Chequers Act of 1917, which was given Royal Assent on 20 December 1917, established the house as the country residence of the Prime Minister. In the past, most PMs were landed aristocrats who already had country retreats, but for those with lesser means like Lloyd George it was necessary to have an estate to host foreign dignitaries and the like.  Interestingly, this was the first Act of Parliament to even acknowledge the existence of a Prime Minister, even though the title had been used unofficially for over a century. Since Lloyd George first stayed there in 1921, Chequers has been used by PMs for crunch summits and meetings like today’s - but also for family Chrsitmases and simply relaxing weekends amid the stresses of office. title: bananas could brink extinction devastating
story: NewsBananas could be on brink of extinction if devastating tropical disease spreads across crops worldwideKnown as Panama disease, the fungal infection has already spread throughout Asia, Africa, the Middle East, Australia, and Central America&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud16:35, 6 JUL 2018NewsIf the infection reaches South America, the popular Cavendish banana could face extinction (Image: EyeEm)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBananas could be on the brink of extinction if a devastating tropical disease spreads across crops worldwide, researchers have warned. Known as Panama disease, the fungal infection has already spread throughout Asia, Africa, the Middle East, Australia and Central America. But if the infection reaches South America the Cavendish banana – the species most commonly sold and consumed worldwide – could face extinction. Cavendish bananas are genetically identical to one another, which allows Panama disease to rapidly decimate entire harvest yields. Some five billion Cavendish bananas are eaten each year in the UK alone.  But salvation for banana crops could come in the form of a rare Madagascan tree, which grows an unpalatable, wild species of banana that is immune to Panama disease. Plant biologists are rushing to create a hybrid of the two species of banana in the hope of creating a infection-resistant strain. But there are only five Madagascan banana trees in existence. The disease does not affect the fruit itself, but rapidly kills Cavendish banana plants.

title: brave great gran reveals how
story: NewsBrave great-gran reveals how she used BACK SCRATCHER to fight off burglar inside her flatPensioner Joyce Ross, 73, stood up to the "scruffy" stranger who broke into her flat in Byker, Newcastle, as she sat down to eat dinner - and she wasn't giving up without a fight&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie Doughty16:41, 6 JUL 2018NewsGranny Joyce Ross wasn't going to give up without a fight (Image: newcastle chronicle)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA great-grandmother has chased off a burglar - using a souvenir back scratcher from Benidorm. Joyce Ross had settled down to eat her dinner when she heard someone entering her ground floor flat through the front door.  Her suspicions were immediately aroused, so the brave OAP armed herself with the back scratcher and urged the scruffy stranger to get out, Chronicle Live reports .  But in an ordeal lasting around 20 minutes, the burglar barged past the 73-year-old and refused to leave her flat despite Joyce repeatedly asking him what he wanted and shouted at him to get out. The pensioner stood her ground and eventually sent him packing when she picked up the back scratcher she keeps to deal with annoying itches, and chased him with it.  Detectives are still hunting the man, who snatched Joyce’s handbag before he fled. And the courageous victim has told why she had to stand up to the invader. She said: “I stayed in control and I just wanted to get him out. I don’t think it has sunk in yet, but I do think I was quite brave now. “I stood up to him because he came into my house. He had no right to just walk into my home like that. He pushed his luck and I think I shocked him by standing up to him. The shock and the anger just kicked in.” Joyce, of Byker, Newcastle, was sitting on her sofa watching television when the man crept in at around 6.15pm on Monday.  She had earlier closed the blinds on her front window to stop the glare from the early-evening sun hitting her screen. When Joyce first heard her front door open she assumed it was a member of her family letting themselves in. But she went to investigate after calling out and getting no answer. And as she reached the doorway she was confronted by a tall stranger who was standing in her hall mumbling to himself. “I could tell that he was really out of it,” said Joyce. “He never spoke, he just mumbled to himself. “I said: ‘Get out, get out. Just tell us what you want but get out’. My defence was just shouting and I was waving my arms, but he seemed oblivious to it. He didn’t say a thing, then he moved forward.”  The man then pushed Joyce against the door frame as he walked into her lounge. “He was just standing there mumbling,” she continued. “He wasn’t saying anything or doing anything so I just didn’t know what he wanted. If he had asked for a packet of tabs I would have given them to him just to get him out.” Joyce picked up the blunt table knife that had been on the tray next to her tea, but the intruder knocked it out her hand. She reached for her phone and tried to dial 999, but again he took the handset off her.  Determined Joyce then spotted the back scratcher her granddaughter had bought home as a present from a holiday in Benidorm, which she always keeps near her sofa. “It wasn’t really to use as a weapon, it was just a threat,” she said. The man quickly grabbed something from the coffee table and ran out the front door and fled down the street. It wasn’t until Joyce returned to the living room that she realised her bag, containing two purses and a mobile phone, had gone. Joyce then called the police.  She was treated at her home by paramedics for a small cut to her head sustained in the struggle. And detectives are now appealing for help from the public to identify the man, while praising Joyce for her bravery. Det Sgt Tony Scott, of Northumbria Police, said: “The man responsible is most likely an opportunist thief so people would have seen him on Denmark Street before this incident. “He has entered the house through an unlocked door and been able to make off with Ms Ross’ purse but I am sure he wasn’t anticipating the reception he received. “Ms Ross showed great courage to stand up to the man and force him from her home. We are making sure she is safe and supported but I want to praise her for her actions.”
